title: Roberts's triangle theorem
summary: Roberts's triangle theorem, a result in discrete geometry, states that every simple arrangement of n {\displaystyle n} lines has at least n âˆ’ 2 {\displaystyle n-2} triangular faces. Thus, three lines form a triangle, four lines form at least two triangles, five lines form at least three triangles, etc. It is named after Samuel Roberts, a British mathematician who published it in 1889.[1][2]
